children.subject: I've taken all the courses you have but only 61c out of the ones you're seeking advice on – I do feel that 61c was far and away the most fulfilling course I've taken so far at Cal. I took it with Garcia last fall. The projects were interesting and although the specs were a little bit unclear at times they were really worthwhile. It depends on personal interest though, 61c is very much straddling the boundary between the physical aspects of computing and the software side, whereas 170 is straight mathy algs and 189 is ML.
Also, if your favorite class out of the ones you listed was 61B, like myself, then 170 will be the most enjoyable, I'd say. It's a lot like a deeper understanding of 61B material using CS 70 skills.

(Sorry for the spamming) 170 typically also has a single, rather open-ended and low stress project which allows you to use any combination of the algorithms you learned in class and typically any open-source tools to solve a challenging problem, which is very fulfilling as it lets you think about everything you learned and figure out how to apply it to a real-world problem, which was quite different from the usual everyone-do-this and debug sort of CS project.

I'd say probably 170 since it seems like you'd be well prepared for it (based on your previous courses). It contains glimpses of material from several different areas of knowledge (data structures, algorithms, statistics, complex numbers, logic, etc.) and in my opinion it is one of the most interesting courses in the department. It's probably a little less time consuming than 189 for most, but based on the classes you've taken (assuming you haven't done EE 126/127 or a relevant stats/probability course), it seems like you may not get the most out of it (though many with the background knowledge you have take it anyway). 61C has a lot of content, so if you can absorb it all and you like computer architecture, you will probably enjoy that most. However, if you're like me and you aren't able to devote all your time to it/don't like architecture that much, it may just be a huge pain. It's like a big overview of how a computer works without going too deep into any of the areas of computer architecture (see 152 and beyond for that).

My particular interests lie in theory, just as a disclaimer.

Haven't taken 189, but from what I've heard, a lot of the course content is theoretical in nature, which I think people don't really expect going into the class. Also I've heard it's a lot of work, which may or may not cool off any enthusiasm you have about machine learning.

I thought 61C conceptually was pretty cool, but the execution of the class was subpar in my opinion. There are a lot of concepts that need to be covered in an extremely short amount of time, which meant that I didn't really get a chance to focus on the interesting bits and had to slog out the remainder of the material. 61C is a really good introduction to low level CS and will prepare you well for any of the 16x classes while giving you a solid foundational understanding of how a computer works. 61C moves fast and is a decent amount of work (esp. some of the projects, oh boy).

My personal opinion is that 170 is the second best class I've ever taken at Cal. I think 170 really introduces you well to the field of theoretical computer science in a way that isn't contrived or excruciatingly annoying. If you enjoyed 61B and 70, I think you'll have a good time in 170. From a coursework perspective, I think 170 moves at a proper pace so you can cover the material efficiently while making sure you learn all of it and everything ties together pretty well in my opinion. 170 should prepare you well for any other sort of theory work you want to do in the future (complexity, approximations, etc) and should prepare you at least somewhat well for 188 and some grad classes. 170 I think is the easiest of the classes listed here since it really sets you up to succeed.

Same poster as f3, I think 188 was actually the best class I took here. Since I haven't taken 189, you can take this with a grain of salt but I believe the concepts in 188 build well off of the skills you learn in 70 (conditional probability mostly) extremely well. I found I was fairly lost after 70 and 188 did an excellent job to ground the knowledge I gained in 70 and made the material a lot easier to understand in the end. Also, I think the course is set up in a way that helps students succeed by covering the material at a good pace that allows you to understand what's going on without being lost.  I didn't find 188 that time intensive and have heard that 189 is a significant amount of work. I would suggest taking 188 first because it feels like a better intro to upper div classes in my opinion. As with all advice on piazza, YMMV.
Is cs 188 or 189 harder? Which one has more rigorous concepts and more time consuming? Or better said, which one should be taken as the first cs upper div?

history.content: I'll take 170, thank you everyone for your detailed inputs :)

Not looking to get a CS job/internship, just want to take an interesting/fulfilling class. Which ones would you say are the least or most challenging or time-consuming? I've taken CS 61A/B/70 and Math 53/54.
history.subject: Most fun class out of CS 189/170/61C?
